record.PhyDescription: Heart of the race horse Phar Lap. Phar Lap's heart weighs 6.35kg, which is significantly larger than an average horse heart of three to four kilograms. A triangular section has been removed. The heart is preserved as a 'wet specimen' submersed in a formalin solution, sealed inside a rectangular clear perspex container.
record.PhyContentDescription: Phar Lap was a late foal, born on 4 October 1926. He had been bred in New Zealand and sold for 160 pounds as Lot 41 at the annual Trentham Yearling Sales in 1927. Harry Telford, a down-on-his-luck Sydney trainer, had spotted the chestnut colt in the sale catalogue and thought that, with the horse's pedigree, it had the potential to become a success. He persuaded American businessman David J Davis to purchase the colt sight unseen. Upon first seeing his new horse, Davis is reported to have said simply, "Harry, I don't like the horse." Davis wanted nothing more to do with the ugly colt, who was gangly and had a face covered in warts. Davis and Telford came to an agreement, whereby Telford would cover the costs associated with the horse as part of a 3-year lease.
record.CreProvenance: This is the preserved heart of the race horse Phar Lap, a champion racehorse in the late 1920s and early 1930s. It is unusually large - 6.2 kg against the average 4 kg size of a horse's heart. A triangular section has been removed, which it is believed was taken for a biopsy. The heart is preserved as a 'wet specimen' submersed in a formalin solution, sealed inside a rectangular clear perspex container. Other parts of Phar Lap are held by other museums - his skeleton is at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, and his hide is at Museum Victoria.

AssociatedParty.AssPersonNotes_tab: Telford was Phar Lap's trainer, and presented the heart to the Australian Institute of Anatomy.
Woodcock was Phar Lap's strapper in Australia, and travelled with him to America in the role of trainer. Woodcock was with Phar Lap when he died.
The heart was displayed at the Institute before it was transferred to the National Museum of Australia.

Phar Lap died at Menlo Park in suspicious circumstances.
The heart was displayed for many years at the Australian Institute of Anatomy in Canberra, and is now in the care of the National Museum of Australia.
